journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Reconstruction of Osteochondral Lesions of the Talus With Autologous Spongiosa Grafts and Autologous Matrix-Induced Chondrogenesis

article-meta.aff: *Orthopaedic Department, University of Basel Hospital, Basel, Switzerland
†Department of Orthopedics, Trauma Surgery and Spinal Cord Injury, Clinic for Orthopedics and Trauma Surgery, Heidelberg University Hospital, Heidelberg, Germany
‡Center for Advanced Orthopedic Studies, Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center, Harvard Medical School, Boston, Massachusetts
Investigation performed at the Orthopaedic Department, University of Basel Hospital, Basel, Switzerland

author-notes.corresp: §Martin Wiewiorski, MD, Orthopaedic Department, University of Basel Hospital, Spitalstrasse 21, 4031 Basel, Switzerland (e-mail: wiewiorskim@gmail.com).

fn.p: Drs Valderrabano and Miska contributed equally to this study.

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: Osteochondral lesions (OCLs) of the talus are a common entity in sports orthopaedics. There are several operative techniques with a good outcome on follow-up examinations. However, limitations such as sacrificing healthy cartilage (osteochondral autograft transfer system [OATS], mosaicplasty), multiple-stage operative procedures (matrix-induced autologous chondrocyte transplantation [MACI], autologous chondrocyte implantation [ACI]), high costs (ACI, allograft), and limited availability (allograft) do remain and reflect potential drawbacks of the currently used techniques.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To describe a novel operative technique for the treatment of OCLs of the talus in the form of an economically efficient, 1-step procedure combining OCL debridement, spongiosaplasty, and sealing of the OCL area with a collagen matrix.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: Twenty-six patients underwent surgery receiving a modified autologous matrix-induced chondrogenesis (AMIC)–aided repair of OCLs of the talus consisting of debridement, autologous grafting, and sealing of the defect with a collagen scaffold. Ligament repair was performed in 17 of 26 cases. A corrective calcaneal osteotomy was performed in 16 of 26 cases. Clinical and radiological assessment was performed before and a minimum of 24 months after surgery (mean, 31 months; range, 24-54 months). Clinical examination included the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) ankle score and the visual analog scale (VAS) for pain. Radiological imaging included single-photon emission computed tomography–computed tomography (SPECT-CT) and magnetic resonance imaging (MRI). The magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) score was applied, and sport activity was documented.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: The AOFAS ankle score improved significantly from a mean of 60 points preoperatively (range, 17-79 points) to 89 points (range, 61-100 points) postoperatively (P < .01). The preoperative pain score averaged 5 (range, 2-8), improving to an average of 1.6 (range, 0-7) postoperatively (P < .01). The MOCART score for cartilage repair tissue on postoperative MRI averaged 62 points (range, 20-95 points). Complete filling of the defect at the level of the surrounding cartilage was found in 35%, and complete filling with a hypertrophic cartilage layer was found in 50% of the patients. Normal signal intensity of the repair tissue compared with the adjacent native cartilage was seen in 15%, with nearly normal activity in 69%. Nineteen patients (73%) participated in sports before the onset of symptoms compared with 3 (12%) at the time of surgery. The number increased to 16 patients (62%) at postoperative follow-up.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The modified AMIC procedure is safe for the treatment of OCLs in the ankle with overall good clinical and MRI results.

body.p: Chronic osteochondral lesions (OCLs) of the ankle joint are commonly related to sports and trauma and are mostly located on the medial or lateral talar edge.23,53,54 The natural history of these lesions is not well known. Previous trauma is reported to be the main cause of OCLs in lateral lesions (93%-98%) and less in medial lesions (61%-70%).21,58 Nontraumatic OCLs have been described in identical twins and relatives.2,64 Other etiological factors than genetics have been discussed such as ischemia with necrosis and endocrine or vascular factors.1,13,58

Frequently, OCLs require operative treatment, despite well-performed nonoperative treatments consisting of anti-inflammatory drugs, viscosupplementation, physical therapy, and orthotics.13,31,46 The currently most used operative methods include debridement with or without microfracturing,6,19 osteochondral autograft transfer system (OATS, mosaicplasty),33-35 autologous chondrocyte implantation (ACI),23 matrix-induced autologous chondrocyte transplantation (MACI),49 or bulk osteochondral allograft transplantation.48 Although several studies report positive postoperative results for those techniques,22,37,49,50 they are associated with several drawbacks.

For the OATS procedures, 1 or more osteochondral cylinders are typically harvested from the knee joint, sacrificing a healthy joint and causing significant and painful donor site morbidity.56 Furthermore, graft mismatch is frequently encountered because of the difference in joint surface curvature, thickness, and biochemical and biomechanical properties of the knee joint and the talar cartilage, respectively.38,51 Cellular-based techniques, such as ACI and MACI, require a 2-stage operative procedure, where initial harvesting of cartilage is followed by culturing and subsequent implantation of the cultured tissue. These techniques are relatively expensive procedures, not currently refunded by all health insurance companies,15 and do not address the bony lesion.62 Bulk fresh talar allografts are expensive, have risks of host graft rejection, and are often not readily available in many countries because of juridical issues.48

To overcome such issues, we adapted and modified a technique previously used for the treatment of full-thickness cartilage lesions of the knee joint, autologous matrix-induced chondrogenesis (AMIC), for the ankle joint. Initially introduced by Behrens,7 the AMIC technique presents a single-step cartilage repair procedure combining debridement of the cartilage lesion and microfracturing of the subchondral bone to release bone marrow containing mesenchymal stem cells (MSCs).9,28 The defect is then covered by a commercially available collagen I/III matrix to stabilize the resulting blood clot. The membrane scaffold is fixed with autologous or partial autologous fibrin glue.27 The OCLs of the talus typically are associated with large cystic osseous lesions. Therefore, we modified the existing AMIC technique by adding MSC-rich autologous cancellous bone from the iliac crest to reconstruct the bony defect underneath the cartilage.55
The purpose of the present study was to describe this novel technique combining spongiosa bone grafts and AMIC for OCLs of the talus in a prospective patient cohort.

sec.title: Patients
sec.p: The study cohort consisted of 26 consecutive patients with talar OCLs (8 female, 18 male; mean age, 33 years; range, 17-55 years) admitted to our tertiary orthopaedic department with unilateral chronic foot and ankle pain. Patients with a first-time OCL diagnosis or failure of a previous operative OCL treatment were included (Table 1). All sizes of OCLs were included. Patients were not considered for surgery if they had an age of greater than 55 years, an unfused distal tibial physis, or involvement of the tibial side of the ankle (kissing lesion).

caption.p: Clinical and Radiological Variables of Patientsa

fn.label: a
fn.p: OCL, osteochondral lesion; AOFAS, American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society hindfoot scale; VAS, visual analog scale; MOCART, magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue; Pre, preoperative; Post, postoperative; M, male; F, female; R, right; L, left; Y, yes; N, no; CL, calcaneal lengthening osteotomy; MS, calcaneal medial sliding osteotomy.

sec.p: Previous ankle trauma was reported by 21 of the 26 patients. The left and right ankle were involved in 13 cases each (Table 1). The medial talar edge was involved in 22 patients, while the lateral edge was involved in 4 patients (Table 1). Ten patients had 1 prior OCL surgery, 2 patients had 2 prior surgeries, and 2 patients had 3 prior surgeries. These included debridement/microfracturing (n = 12), OATS from the knee (n = 5), and retrograde drilling (n = 3) (Table 1).

sec.title: Clinical and Radiological Assessment
sec.p: Clinical and radiological assessment was performed before and a minimum of 24 months after surgery (mean, 31 months; range, 24-54 months). Prospectively collected data included clinical assessment with the American Orthopaedic Foot and Ankle Society (AOFAS) ankle score36 and pain status measured by a visual analog scale (VAS) (use of a 10-cm graded line, with 0 indicating no pain and 10 indicating the worst pain imaginable).14 The level of sports activity and type of sports were documented for 3 time points: before the onset of symptoms, immediately before surgery, and at the time of the follow-up examination (Table 2).57

tr.td: Moderate level of sports activity in leisure time, <1 h/wk
Normal level of sports activity in leisure time, 1-5 h/wk
High level of sports activity in leisure time, <5 h/wk
Professional level of sports activity in leisure time, elite athlete

sec.p: All patients in this case series underwent preoperative radiological imaging of the foot and ankle consisting of standard weightbearing radiographs (Figure 1A), native anatomic magnetic resonance imaging (MRI; 3- dimensional fluid-tissue contrast-enhanced dual echo steady state [DESS] sequence; voxel size of 0.4 × 0.4 × 3.0 mm, field of view of 140 × 140 mm, repetition time of 16.87 ms, and echo time of 4.3 ms) (Figure 1B), and 3-plane single-photon emission computed tomography–computed tomography (SPECT-CT) (Figure 1, C and D). Lesion volume was calculated with the use of preoperative frontal, axial, and sagittal SPECT-CT reformats. The average volume of the lesions was 1680 mm3 (range, 378-7054 mm3) (Table 1). Subchondral cysts were noted in 18 of 26 cases. Morphological appearance of the cartilage repair tissue was assessed on sagittal DESS sequences according to the magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) protocol.42,59 The MOCART score was evaluated by a senior radiologist who specialized in musculoskeletal imaging and was blinded to the clinical results and patient data.

caption.p: Preoperative imaging of medial osteochondral lesion of the talus. Demonstrated is case 12 from Table 1. (A) Initial conventional radiographs show no signs of subchondral talar bone abnormality. (B) On magnetic resonance imaging, coronal T2-weighted sequences show a cystic subchondral lesion with an inhomogeneous and partly disrupted cartilage layer over the lesion. (C, D) Single-photon emission computed tomography–computed tomography (SPECT-CT) reveals the actual extent of the bony defect with highly increased bone remodeling activity.

sec.title: Operative Technique
sec.p: All surgeries were performed by the first author (V.V.). The procedure was performed either with spinal or general anesthesia in the supine position. A tourniquet was applied. All patients received a single dose of 1 g of intravenous cefazolin 1 hour before skin incision. An initial arthroscopic procedure of the ankle joint was performed to verify the size and location of the defect and the condition of the lateral and medial ankle ligaments. A standard anteromedial or anterolateral approach for arthrotomy was used, depending on OCL location (Figure 2A). If the OCL could not be accessed after capsular incision, a malleolar osteotomy was performed: medial malleolar osteotomy in all but 1 case of medial OCLs (21/22) and lateral malleolar osteotomy in a single case (1/4). The defective cartilage and the typically necrotic and sclerotic bony lesion underneath were precisely debrided and microdrilled (Figure 2B and 2D). In cases of subchondral cyst(s), the cysts were debrided, and their sclerotic wall was microdrilled. Sequentially, spongiosa bone, which is known to be rich with MSCs,12 was harvested from the iliac crest through a limited incision and was smoothly impacted into the debrided talar bony defect (Figure 2E). Next, a commercially available acellular collagen I/III matrix (Chondro-Gide, Geistlich Surgery, Wolhusen, Switzerland) was prepared. The bilayer matrix of porcine collagen has a compact and a porous side. The compact layer consists of a compact, cell-occlusive surface, preventing the blood coagulate and the graft from diffusing into the joint space. The porous layer of the matrix is composed of loose collagen fibers that support cell invasion and the ingrowth of newly formed tissue.

caption.p: Operative procedure of medial osteochondral lesion of the talus. Demonstrated is case 12 (Table 1 and Figure 1). (A) Osteotomy of the medial malleolus revealed an impressive chondral defect at the posteromedial talar edge. (B) The chondral/osteochondral fragment was sharply detached from the surrounding healthy cartilage. Subsequently, the sclerotic subchondral bone was broken down to debride the underlying cyst seen on preoperative imaging (C), followed by microfracturing (D). (E) Spongiosa harvested from the iliac crest was impacted into the defect. (F) The cut-to-shape collagen membrane was glued on top of the defect.

sec.p: An aluminum template was used to determine the OCL size on the talar situs. The cut-to-size matrix was glued onto the defect over the spongiosa bone graft with a commercially available fibrin glue (Tissucol, Baxter, Deerfield, Illinois). For the knee joint, Drobnic et al18 showed that fibrin glue fixation provides primary stability comparable with suture fixation of a collagen membrane. Care was taken not to overlap the surrounding healthy cartilage with the matrix (Figure 2F). Then, the ankle was moved several times throughout the whole range of motion, and correct positioning of the membrane was checked.

If the preoperative examination and radiographs showed malalignment of the hindfoot (defined as ≥10° of hindfoot valgus), a corrective calcaneal osteotomy was performed (16/26 cases; 15 calcaneal lengthening osteotomy, 1 calcaneal medial sliding osteotomy). If ankle joint instability was noted during the clinical examination (positive anterior drawer and inversion test finding) and confirmed by ankle arthroscopic surgery, ligament repair was performed using a modified Brostrom-Gould procedure.32 Ligament repair was performed in 17 of 26 cases (3 lateral, 1 medial, 13 mediolateral).

sec.title: Postoperative Care
sec.p: Postoperative care consisted of immobilization using a walker (Aircast Walker, DJO Global, Vista, California) and functional physical therapy with 15-kg partial weightbearing, maximal range of motion of 20° with a continuous passive motion machine, and lymphatic drainage massage for the first 6 weeks. This initial phase was followed by an intensive rehabilitation phase with progression to full weightbearing and strengthening of the ankle joint stabilizing lower leg muscles and proprioception training for the following 6 weeks (ie, up to 12 weeks). The patients were seen in the outpatient clinic 6 and 12 weeks after the surgery for a clinical follow-up examination and conventional radiographs. After 12 weeks, light sports exercise (swimming, cycling) were allowed. Return to competitive sports was allowed after 5 to 6 months. Postoperative care was identical for cases with corrective osteotomy and/or ligament reconstruction.

The study was approved by the institutional review board, and written informed patient consent was obtained. The study was carried out in accordance with the World Medical Association Declaration of Helsinki. Statistical analysis was performed with use of a standard paired t test by an independent statistician.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: The AOFAS ankle score improved significantly from a mean of 60 points preoperatively (range, 17-79 points) to 89 points (range, 61-100 points) postoperatively (P < .01). The preoperative VAS pain score averaged 5 (range, 2-8). The score improved to an average of 1.6 (range, 0-7) (P < .01). No significant difference was found for the postoperative AOFAS ankle score and VAS score when comparing patients with first-time surgery and revision surgery (P > .05). No intraoperative or postoperative complications were encountered.

Before the onset of symptoms, 6 patients (23%) participated in no sports (level 0), 3 patients (12%) had a sport activity of level 1, 11 patients (42%) of level 2, 5 patients (4%) of level 3, and 1 patient of level 4. At the time of surgery, 23 patients (88%) participated in no sports (level 0), 2 patients (8%) had a sport activity of level 2, and 1 patient (4%) of level 3. At postoperative follow-up examination, 10 patients (38%) had a sport activity level of 0, 3 patients (11%) of level 1, 11 patients (42%) of level 2, 1 patient (4%) of level 3, and 1 patient (4%) of level 4. Nine of the 20 patients (45%) participating in any sport activity before the onset of symptoms returned to their previous activity level at follow-up. The sport activities for each case are shown in Appendix 1 (available in the online version of this article at http://ajs.sagepub.com/supplemental/).

The MOCART score (Table 3) for cartilage repair tissue on postoperative MRI averaged 62 points (range, 20-95 points). Complete filling of the defect at the level of the surrounding cartilage was found in 35%, and complete filling with a hypertrophic cartilage layer was found in 50% of the patients (Figure 3). Normal signal intensity of the repair tissue compared with the adjacent native cartilage was seen in 15%, with nearly normal activity in 69%.

tr.td: Degree of defect repair and filling of the defect
Signal intensity of the repair tissue
Nearly normal (slight areas of signal alteration) (15)

fn.label: a
fn.p: Magnetic resonance imaging evaluation of cartilage repair tissue by using the magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) score. Adapted from Welsch et al.59

caption.p: Postoperative imaging of medial osteochondral lesion of the talus. Demonstrated is case 12 (Table 1 and Figures 1 and 2). Postoperative T1-weighted magnetic resonance imaging scan shows an intact homogeneous cartilage cover over the reconstructed lesion with a total magnetic resonance observation of cartilage repair tissue (MOCART) score of 70.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this study, we present the first prospectively obtained clinical and radiological results of the iliac crest spongiosa graft–aided AMIC reconstruction of OCLs of the talus after a minimal follow-up of 24 months. Our study confirms the positive results that were described in 2 previously reported cases.60,61 In the current cohort, the clinical results for the AOFAS score at 1-year follow-up are comparable with the results for other operative techniques (Appendix 2, available online).3,23,50,53,56 Previous reports regarding the AMIC-aided cartilage repair technique focus on operative treatment of trochlear and retropatellar cartilage lesions of the knee joint.8,9 Several clinical outcome studies have reported good results for short-term follow-up.30,43,52 However, those studies addressed purely cartilaginous lesions and not OCLs.

We performed a reconstruction of the subchondral bone by impacting cancellous bone from the iliac crest into the defect created by debridement. Antegrade17,39 and retrograde41,53 cancellous bone grafting for talar OCLs have been previously described. Draper and Fallat17 treated 14 patients with autologous spongiosa from the proximal tibia. At follow-up after 71.5 ± 21.1 months, they noted better overall clinical scores, better range of motion, and less pain in comparison with a group of 17 patients with debridement and subchondral drilling as the primary treatment technique. Kolker et al39 retrospectively reviewed a group of 13 patients treated with open bone grafting. Six patients (46%) were clinical failures requiring further surgery. Of the remaining 7 patients, functional outcome results were obtained at a mean of 51.9 months after surgery. The AOFAS hindfoot score improved from 55 to 75 points at a mean follow-up of 37.4 months. Kolker et al39 doubted the success of autologous bone grafting alone as a primary treatment; however, they recommended bone grafting in combination with other cartilage-restoring procedures (ACI, OATS).

In the technique used for this study, the bone graft was sealed against the joint cavity with a collagen matrix. In a similar 1-stage technique for the treatment of large OCLs of the knee joint, bone grafting was combined with a periosteal flap (“sandwich technique”).44,45 The rationale behind this procedure is to restore healthy bony tissue as a base for cartilage regeneration and provide a suitable environment for the formation of cartilaginous repair tissue.

In this study, the iliac crest was chosen as the graft source because it is considered the gold standard for bone grafting and contains bone marrow, which is a rich source of regenerative cells (MSCs) needed for angiogenesis and optimal bone formation and healing.12

Successful ingrowth of the bone graft could be a possible reason for postoperative pain improvement seen in this cohort. Nociceptive fibers have been identified in subchondral bone tissue,10,63 making it a potential contributor to pain in OCLs.62

Other authors have emphasized the role of MSCs in the treatment of chondral lesions and/or OCLs. Gobbi et al29 combined bone marrow concentrate from the iliac crest with the same collagen matrix used in this study to treat chondral defects of the knee. A significant improvement of the clinical parameters was demonstrated at 2-year follow-up. A similar method has been also utilized for OCLs of the talus. Giannini et al24 described a method in which a hyaluronic acid membrane is loaded with bone marrow concentrate and then transplanted onto the lesion. After 29 months’ follow-up, a significant improvement in the mean AOFAS score from 64.4 to 91.4 was demonstrated.

Several authors have reported the advantage of an arthroscopic procedure for the treatment of OCLs of the talus.4,20,41 Arthroscopic treatment can reduce surgical trauma and avoids the need for a tibial or fibular osteotomy and subsequent hardware removal. However, this technique should be reserved for smaller and more easily accessible lesions. The average volume of the lesions encountered in the cohort of this study was 1680 mm3. In the majority of these cases, arthroscopic access would not allow for adequate debridement (removing of fibrous tissue, breaking down sclerotic cysts) of the lesion. However, sufficient debridement is essential for integration of the autologous graft and cartilage repair; therefore, a malleolar osteotomy was performed in 22 of 26 cases. On radiological follow-up, all osteotomies were healed.

Full coverage of the lesion with cartilage repair tissue has been demonstrated on postoperative MRI in 85% of the cases, and the mean MOCART score was 62 points. In a case series of 19 patients treated with MACI, Aurich et al4 reported a mean MOCART score of 62.4 points at a mean follow-up of 24.5 months. Complete filling of the defect was found in 9 of 19 (47%). In a case series of 10 patients, Domayer et al16 assessed a modified MOCART score at a mean follow-up time of 51 months after MACI for talar OCLs. They showed complete filling of the defect in 7 of 10 cases (4 complete filling, 3 hypertrophic complete filling). Quirbach et al47 reported a mean MOCART score after ankle MACI of 73.8 points. All patients of this cohort showed the presence of cartilage repair tissue on postoperative MRI. However, the quality of the repair tissue regarding glycosaminoglycan and collagen content after AMIC-aided repair is still unclear. No posttreatment second-look arthroscopic procedure was performed; therefore, the biochemical characteristics of the repair cartilage have not been assessed.

A single animal study using an ovine knee model assessed the use of the AMIC technique for trochlear cartilage defects and reported the repair tissue to be neocartilage of partly hyaline-like characteristics on histological examination.26 Gobbi et al29 performed cartilage biopsy in 3 cases after a mean of 13.5 months after AMIC combined with bone marrow concentrate. The repair cartilage showed hyaline-like characteristics. Gigante et al25 performed second-look biopsies 12 months after the repair of cartilage lesions in the knee using a collagen type I matrix augmented with bone marrow concentrate, a procedure similar to AMIC. While all samples showed normal arthroscopic appearance, hyaline-like matrix was found in only 1 case, a mixture of hyaline/fibrocartilage was found in 1 case, and fibrocartilage was found in 3 cases.

In the athletic population, talar OCLs usually lead to reduced activity and even a discontinuation of sports.34 In this study, when asked about sport activities on preoperative clinical examination, only 3 of 26 (11%) reported that they were able to perform sport activities. This number increased to 16 patients (62%) at follow-up. Patients recovered to perform sport exercises at a moderate or normal activity level (53%) or even at a high or elite level (8%).

Aurich et al4 reported that 81% of patients undergoing MACI return to the same level of sports as before the onset of symptoms after surgery. In a case series published by Ferkel et al,20 all 60 patients treated arthroscopically (debridement, microdrilling) indicated that they could return to their previous sport of choice. However, contrary to our study, all patients with revision OCL surgery were excluded.

We propose certain advantages over other established surgical techniques. On the one hand, the described AMIC procedure requires one single surgery. Cartilage culturing after initial chondrocyte harvesting and a second-stage reimplantation is not needed. On the other hand, vital cartilage of another joint is spared, and therefore, donor site morbidity is reduced.56 One downside is that an additional surgical site is needed to harvest the cancellous bone. The collagen membrane used with the described technique is a readily available “off-the-shelf” item. From an economic point of view, the AMIC-aided procedure is a cost-effective treatment method. The costs of open ACI surgery for cartilage lesions of the knee joint total US$13,600 ($8500 for the procedure plus $4800 for in vitro cell expansion) compared with $3700 for microfracturing.15 A bulk talar allograft is reported to cost about $6500.11 The costs of AMIC-aided treatment are comparable with microfracturing, adding the costs for the collagen matrix. The particular collagen matrix used for this study is currently not approved by the US Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and is not available in North America.

The authors are aware of several limitations of the present study. The majority of the patients in this study had previous ankle trauma (21/25) and suffered from ankle joint instability (17/26), which was addressed by additional ligament repair. In addition, increased hindfoot valgus was addressed with a calcaneal osteotomy in 16 of 26 cases. A bias was introduced by the additional procedures. However, the authors believe that changing a pathomechanical joint into an almost normal biomechanical joint by correcting osseous malalignment and improving joint stability might be essential for healing of the reconstructed defect. Otherwise, remaining pathological stress on the repair tissue will eventually lead to graft failure and new pain symptoms. However, the role of instability and malalignment in the treatment of OCLs of the talus is not fully understood, and evidence is sparse. Ligament repair in cases of talar OCLs accompanied by ankle joint instability has been previously described in a few cases only.22,40 Regarding corrective osteotomies, Giannini et al22 reported 1 case of metatarsal osteotomy in the presence of a cavus foot. Aurich et al5 regarded concomitant treatment of posttraumatic deformities (malalignment), ligamentous instabilities, and reconstruction of bony defects as compulsory for successful OCL repair.

A case series without a control group is presented. The population described in this group is a mixed cohort of difficult-to-treat patients with large osseous defects including revisions of previously failed surgeries. However, the clinical and radiological variables showed no statistically significant difference between those groups at follow-up. No posttreatment second-look arthroscopic procedure was performed; therefore, the biochemical characteristics of the repair cartilage have not been assessed.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: The modified AMIC technique is a promising novel method for the operative treatment of OCLs of the talus. Good clinical and radiological results were presented after a follow-up of 24 months. The patients returned to sport in the majority of the cases. The described technique is cost effective, is readily available, and can be performed as a single surgery for initial operative treatment or revision surgery of OCLs of the talus. Further clinical and radiological results will show its usefulness in comparison with conventionally used operative repair techniques.

ack.p: The authors thank Ueli Studler and Martin Kretzschmar from the Department of Radiology of the University of Basel Hospital for their invaluable help in this study.

fn.p: One or more of the authors has declared the following potential conflict of interest or source of funding: The radiological imaging used in this study was funded by Geistlich Pharma AG, Wolhusen, Switzerland.
